rtega_mnemonic:
夊夊RSgo slowly, foot, rad. 35
  • foot walking slowly → 夊
origin_of_ch_char_book: (思, si=ssu, think) describes a head with a knot which has a complex thought (x). There is a heart which means emotions in below the character. The ancients believed that human emotions came from the heart, and complex and logical thoughts come from head. This character is a combination of thoughts and emotions that have mixed feelings of mind and soul. (愛, 爱, ai, love) A person stands tall, with his/her mouth widely opened , breathing long (like Yawning) with heart (心) in it, and with a foot down to the designated place (夊) below. It describes one’s mind heartily heads to one’s loved one.
humanum_full_description_en: "夊" oracle bone inscriptions are the reverse writing of " stop ", like the shape of the sole of the foot downward; while " stop " is like the sole of the foot upward. " Stop ", " additional information " as the ancient text parts, sometimes no other, and said foot, see " Wei ", " Wai ." Sometimes it has different meanings because of the different direction of the soles of the feet. For example, " Zhi " goes upward from the second stop, which means climbing, and " Descending " means going down from the second stop. Therefore, "夊" is separated to indicate the downward foot, see " stop ". "Shuowen": "Kai, walking delay and flicking Kuaikuai, like a person's two legs have a spine. All the belongings of Kui are from Kuai." It refers to the slow walking of people. "Yu Pian·Kai Bu": "Kai, thinking and cutting, looking late. "Poetry" says: "Xionghu Kuaikuai". Kuaikui, the present "Book of Songs‧Qifeng‧Nanshan" is "Suisui".
humanum_short_description_en: "夊" oracle bone inscription is the reverse of " stop ".
humanum_full_description: 「夊」甲骨文為「止」的倒寫，象腳掌向下之形；而「止」則象腳掌向上。「止」、「夊」作為古文字部件，有時無別，均表示腳掌，參見「韋」、「圍」。有時則因腳掌方向不同而意義有別，如「陟」從二止向上，表示登山，「降」從二止向下，表示下山。因此分出「夊」以表示向下的腳掌，參見「止」。《說文》：「夊，行遲曳夊夊，象人兩脛有所躧也。凡夊之屬皆从夊。」即指人之步履遲緩。《玉篇·夊部》：「夊，思隹切，行遲貌。《詩》云：『雄狐夊夊』」。夊夊，今本《詩經‧齊風‧南山》作「绥绥」。

origin_of_ch_char_book: (思, si=ssu, think) describes a head with a knot which has a complex thought (x). There is a heart which means emotions in below the character. The ancients believed that human emotions came from the heart, and complex and logical thoughts come from head. This character is a combination of thoughts and emotions that have mixed feelings of mind and soul. (愛, 爱, ai, love) A person stands tall, with his/her mouth widely opened , breathing long (like Yawning) with heart (心) in it, and with a foot down to the designated place (夊) below. It describes one’s mind heartily heads to one’s loved one.
夊夊RS go slowly, foot, rad. 35
  • foot walking slowly → 夊

「 夊 」甲骨文為「 止 」的倒寫，象腳掌向下之形；而「 止 」則象腳掌向上。「 止 」、「 夊 」作為古文字部件，有時無別，均表示腳掌，參見「 韋 」、「 圍 」。有時則因腳掌方向不同而意義有別，如「 陟 」從二止向上，表示登山，「 降 」從二止向下，表示下山。因此分出「 夊 」以表示向下的腳掌，參見「 止 」。《說文》：「夊，行遲曳夊夊，象人兩脛有所躧也。凡夊之屬皆从夊。」即指人之步履遲緩。《玉篇·夊部》：「夊，思隹切，行遲貌。《詩》云：『雄狐夊夊』」。夊夊，今本《詩經‧齊風‧南山》作「绥绥」。
" 夊" oracle bone inscriptions are the reverse writing of " stop", like the shape of the sole of the foot downward; while " stop" is like the sole of the foot upward. " Stop", " additional information" as the ancient text parts, sometimes no other, and said foot, see " Wei", " Wai." Sometimes it has different meanings because of the different direction of the soles of the feet. For example, " Zhi" goes upward from the second stop, which means climbing, and " Descending" means going down from the second stop. Therefore, " 夊" is separated to indicate the downward foot, see " stop". "Shuowen": "Kai, walking delay and flicking Kuaikuai, like a person's two legs have a spine. All the belongings of Kui are from Kuai." It refers to the slow walking of people. "Yu Pian·Kai Bu": "Kai, thinking and cutting, looking late. "Poetry" says: "Xionghu Kuaikuai". Kuaikui, the present "Book of Songs‧Qifeng‧Nanshan" is "Suisui".
夊：suī ㄙㄨㄟˉ。《说文解字》：“夊，行迟曳夊夊，象人两胫有所躧也。”。走路时象人两胫有所拖着一样慢是夊之范式。
本义：用作“夊夊”。古同“绥绥”，慢慢行走的样子，如“雄狐夊夊。”（今作“有狐绥绥”）。
Sui: suī ㄙㄨㄟˉ. " Shuowen Jiezi ": "Kai, when the line is late and drags Kuaikuai, like people have two legs .". Walking as slow as a person’s shins is the paradigm of Kui.
Original meaning: used as "夊夊". In ancient times, " Sui Sui ", walking slowly, like "Xionghu Kuaikuai." (now called "Youhu Suisui").
